Structure and activity of strontium substituted LaCoO3 perovskite catalysts for syngas conversion Min Ao a b Gia Hung Pham a ⁎ Valérie Sage b Vishnu Pareek a a Department of Chemical Engineering, Curtin University, GPO Box U1987, Perth, WA 6845, Australia Department of Chemical Engineering Curtin University GPO Box U1987 Perth WA 6845 Australia b CSIRO Energy, ARRC, 26 Dick Perry Avenue, Kensington, WA 6151, Australia CSIRO Energy ARRC 26 Dick Perry Avenue Kensington WA 6151 Australia ⁎ Corresponding author.Fax: +61 892662681. Graphical abstract Study of the catalytic activity of LaCoO3 perovskite catalysts with varying degrees of strontium substitution (La1-x Sr x CoO3) in the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis is presented for the first time in this paper. It was found that Sr substitution improves the catalyst’s reducibility and increasing strontium substitution beyond a threshold of 10mol% Sr has an inverse effect on the catalytic performance in the syngas conversion. For x ≤0.1, the catalysts exhibited a stable rhombohedral structure, which leads to well dispersion of active centre Co0 during the reduction process and displayed a high catalytic activity. For x ≥0.2 the catalyst structure was gradually changed, from a rhombohedral to a less stable cubic structure, and leads to Co0 sintering. The turnover frequency of Co atom in the Fischer–Tropsch reaction decreased significantly with increasing strontium substitution levels due to the loss of active catalyst surface. The La0.9Sr0.1CoO3 catalyst showed the highest catalytic activity in the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis. Keywords LaCoO3 perovskite Strontium substitution Syngas conversion Catalyst structure Rhombohedral structure Catalytic activity Fischer–Tropsch synthesis 1 Introduction Fischer–Tropsch (F–T) synthesis has proven its ability for the conversion of synthesis gas to high value hydrocarbons (e.g. gasoline, diesel and light olefins) and organic oxygenates (e.g. methanol and other higher alcohols) [1]. Cobalt and iron oxides are the most common catalysts for F–T synthesis and have been thoroughly investigated. Recently, perovskite catalysts with an ABO3 type structure, where A and B represent different metallic elements, have been investigated for F–T synthesis, due to the flexibility in their design and preparation. It is envisaged that their tailorable compositions and structures could be used to target specific desirable products of the F–T reaction, such as higher alcohols [2–12]. A large variety of perovskites can be prepared due to their generally excellent stable structure and capacity to accommodate a wide range of metallic elements with different atomic sizes and oxidation states in each of the A and B sites [2–12]. Each of these perovskite combinations has different physico-chemical properties. In addition, their high thermal stability and excellent redox properties also make perovskite oxides ideal candidates for syngas conversion. For example, a series of La(CoFe)O3 perovskite catalysts have been reported to show high C2–C4 olefins selectivity [3,4]. Tien-Thao and co-workers investigated the performance and stability of the perovskite catalyst LaCo1−x Cu x O3 (x =0–0.4) for syngas conversion, reporting high selectivity for higher alcohol formation [6–10] . Partial substitution at the A or/and B sites of the perovskite (ABO3) leads to changes in the perovskite structure, the oxygen mobility and the redox properties of the perovskite, which affects the catalytic activity. For example, LaMnO3 perovskite, which exhibit a cubic structure, was reported to be active in n-hexane combustion. After partial substitution of Mn by 10mol% Co at the B site, the structure of the catalyst changed to rhombohedral, and the catalytic activity was improved significantly [13] . To further improve the catalyst activity and enhance its redox properties, Pecchi et al. partially substituted La3+ by Ag+ at the A site of the LaMn0.9Co0.1O3 perovskite catalyst and observed a large increase in the catalytic activity. For low silver substitution (x ≤0.2), the segregated silver phase on the catalyst surface enhanced the catalyst activity compared to the unsubstituted catalyst. With increasing Ag+ substitution, the rhombohedral structure of LaMn0.9Co0.1O3 changes to an orthorhombic structure for La0.7Ag0.3Mn0.9Co0.1O3 catalyst, which further enhanced the reaction rate of n-hexane combustion [14]. Partial substitution at the B site was found to be an effective method for improvement of product selectivity in F–T synthesis. Van et al. found that the product selectivity strongly depends on the Cu substitution level of LaTi1- x Cu x O3 catalysts during CO hydrogenation [15]. The effects of partial substitution of La3+ by lower oxidation state ions such as Sr2+ in LaCoO3 perovskites have been widely investigated for both fundamental research and industrial applications such as batteries [16], thermoelectric materials [17] or as a catalyst for steam and hydrocarbon reforming [18]. The catalytic properties of La1-x Sr x CoO3 perovskites have also been studied for the oxidation of carbon monoxide [19,20], hydrocarbons [21–23] and soots [24,25]. It was found that the changes in the perovskite structure of LaCoO3 with partial substitution of La3+ by Sr2+ positively affect the catalytic activity significantly in the above-mentioned applications. However, to the best of our knowledge, there is no specific study about the effect of strontium substitution on LaCoO3 perovskite for syngas conversion. Although other perovskite catalysts for higher alcohol formation from syngas have been investigated intensively to date, product yields still remain too low for commercial applications, with reagent conversion and product selectivity following opposite trends (high selectivity at low conversion and vice versa) [6–12]. The main objective of this study is to investigate the effect of strontium substitution on the catalytic activity of LaCoO3 perovskite in syngas conversion, and to find the optimal La/Sr atom ratio in La1-x Sr x CoO3 perovskite catalysts. To this end, La1- x Sr x CoO3 perovskite catalysts (x =0 to 0.4) were prepared by using the co- precipitation technique and their activity was tested in the F–T synthesis at different reaction temperatures, using a lab scale fixed bed reactor. All the catalysts were thoroughly characterised by different techniques. The result of this work is an important step in the design of catalysts tailored for specific reactions and products, such as the Fischer–Tropsch process for higher alcohol production from syngas. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation La1- x Sr x CoO3 (x =0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4) perovskite catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation. The required amount of lanthanum nitrates (La(NO3) 3·6H2O, Sigma–Aldrich), strontium nitrates (Sr(NO3) 2, Sigma–Aldrich) and cobalt nitrates (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Aldrich) were well dissolved in distilled water. Ammonia water (Aldrich, 35% mass fraction), used as a precipitating agent, was added to the solution dropwise under stirring until a pH of 9 was reached. The precipitate was then filtered and dried at 120°C overnight. The dried material was then calcined in flowing air at 350°C for 3h and then heated to 800°C for 5h, to remove the precursors and obtain the perovskite oxide [26]. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Specific surface area measurements of the catalysts were carried out on a Micro Tristar II apparatus at liquid nitrogen temperature using the BET method. The samples were degassed by evacuation at 250°C for 12h before N2 adsorption measurements. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with Co Kα radiation (λ=1.78897nm) operating at 40kV and 200mA. The spectra were obtained between the 2θ ranges of 20–80° at a scanning speed of 1°/min for fresh catalysts and 5°/min for reduced and used catalysts at room temperature. The patterns recorded were identified by reference to the powder diffraction data (JCPDS-ICDD) with the standard spectra software. Particle sizes of the perovskite were calculated by Scherrer equation applied to the (024) plane at 55°. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were recorded using a Field Emission Zeiss Ultra Plus unit, with an acceleration voltage of 5kV. Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were performed using a ChemBET 3000 equipment. In each analysis, ca. 0.3g of sample in the form of powder was placed in a quartz cell. The sample was outgassed at 300°C for 1h with flowing nitrogen through the cell to remove the contaminants on the surface of the sample and then cooled down to room temperature. The sample was then reduced with a 5% H2/N2 gas mixture at a total flow of 20ml/min. The temperature was increased at 5°C/min from room temperature to 800°C. 2.3 Catalytic performance test The catalytic tests were carried out in a high-pressure experimental unit which consists of three parts: gas feeding system, reaction system and separation and analysis system (Fig. 1 ). The stainless-steel fixed-bed reactor (I.D.=12.7mm, L =385mm) was packed with 1g of catalyst (66–150μm) diluted with alumina (1:10 ratio) in the middle of the reactor. The reaction temperature was monitored by a thermocouple, which was inserted in the middle of the catalyst bed. To avoid condensation of oxygenates and long chain hydrocarbon products (only present in small amount) leaving the reactor, the transfer lines downstream of the catalyst bed were heated to 130°C. Three calibrated mass flow controllers (MFC) were used to regulate the flow of the inlet gases (H2 and N2 with purity of 99.999%, CO purity 99.5%). The reactor pressure was controlled by a back pressure controller (BPC). The pressures at the inlet and outlet of the reactor were recorded during the reaction, to ensure the pressure drop across the catalyst bed was known and could be continually monitored. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was reduced in situ using a gas mixture containing 18.75% H2 in N2 at a flow rate of 160ml/min. The reactor temperature was increased from room temperature to 450°C at a heating rate of 5°C/min and was held at this temperature overnight (about 16h). Then the reactor was cooled down to reaction temperature and pressurised to reaction conditions with nitrogen. A syngas mixture composition of H2/CO/N2 =2:1:3 was used as feed for all experiments in this work. N2 acted as an internal calibration standard. The F–T reaction was carried out at steady state under the reaction conditions of 300°C to 350°C, 3.0MPa, and a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 3500h−1 without considering the N2 (total gas flow 126ml/min). The inlet (using a reactor by-pass) and outlet gases CO, H2, N2, CH4, CO2 and C1–C5 hydrocarbons were analysed on-line with a PerkinElmer CLARUS 580 refinery gas analyser (RGA) equipped with one flame ionization detector (FID) and two thermal conductivity detectors (TCD), and a combination of packed columns (HaySep N, HaySep T, Molecular Sieve and Molecular Sieve 5A). The run time for each experiment was about 24h. The feed gas conversion and other gaseous products were monitored with a time interval of 8min. The liquid products were collected at the end of the run and analysed off-line after being carefully separated by condensation on an Agilent 7890 GC/MS equipped with an HP-5 MS capillary column and a FID detector. Using N2 as an internal standard, the feed gas conversion X F was calculated as: (1) X F = M o l e F in − M o l e F out M o l e F in × 100 % And the molar selectivity of each carbon- containing product calculated as: (2) S A = M o l e A × n A M o l e co react × 100 % where MoleFin and MoleFout is the moles of gas (CO or H2) in the feed-gases and out-gases, respectively; and MoleA, n A represent the moles of carbon-containing product A and the number of carbon atoms in product A, respectively. The experiments were carried out for 24h and the data obtained from each experiment were the average of measurements over the steady-state period (at least 10 measured values) with carbon mass balance error less than ±4%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterisation 3.1.1 Specific surface area (BET) The specific surface area (S BET) of the prepared La1−x Sr x CoO3 perovskite samples are given in Table 1 . Results showed that the specific surface areas of the prepared catalysts were low and the substitution of strontium did not change the S BET significantly. It is well known that the specific surface area of perovskite is affected by the calcination temperature [27]. The measured surface area of LaCoO3 in this work (2.4m2/g with calcination at 800°C) agreed with the reported result in the literature for similar calcination temperature (2.8m2/g for calcination at 850°C) [28] . The surface areas of the La1- x Sr x CoO3 perovskites prepared in this study were lower than those reported by Gao and Wang (10.0m2/g for x =0.1; and 7.4m2/g for x =0.3), with a calcination at the lower temperature (700°C) [21]. 3.1.2 X-ray diffraction (XRD) The XRD patterns of the prepared La1- x Sr x CoO3 perovskite oxides with different strontium substitution levels are presented in Fig. 2 . As for the perovskite-type structure of LaCoO3 (JCPDS-ICDD 48-0123), La1- x Sr x CoO3 (x =0.1, 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4) also exhibit the typical diffraction peaks of the perovskite structure at 2θ ≈38–39° (Fig. 2B), suggesting that calcination temperature at 800°C was suitable for perovskite formation. Similar amounts of Co3O4 (JCPDS-ICDD 80-1541) were found in all samples with very low peak intensity [29]. The diffraction profiles reveal that a well-defined rhombohedral structure was obtained for the La1-x Sr x CoO3 catalysts without or with low strontium substitution (x ≤0.1), with the doublet peak at 2θ ≈38–39° [17,26] . With the increase in strontium substitution levels (x ≥0.2), the typical doublet peak indicative of the rhombohedral structure became weaker and gradually evolved to a singlet peak indicating cubic symmetry [30,31]. Due to the high tolerance of the perovskite structure to distortion with metallic elements of different sizes and oxidation states, substitution of La3+ with a higher ionic radius Sr2+ (1.36Å and 1.44Å, respectively [32]) into the A site of LaCoO3 maintained the rhombohedral structure at low strontium substitution levels (x ≤0.1). At higher strontium substitution levels (x ≥0.2), the symmetry of the crystal structure changed from rhombohedral to cubic [30,31]. Furthermore, due to the different ionic radii between La3+ and Sr2+, the diffraction lines of La1- x Sr x CoO3 progressively shifted to lower 2θ values. As a result, the crystalline domain sizes were markedly diminished from 39–27nm according to the Scherrer equation [17,25] (see Table 1). The slight shift of the peaks observed indicates that strontium ions have entered into the perovskite lattice, as proposed in the literature [27]. The limitation of the solubility of strontium substitution in LaCoO3 perovskite lattice was reported in the literature differently. Schmal et al. [33] suggested that 5mol% of strontium was the maximum limit to form the single phase related to LaCoO3, while Hueso et al. [31] proved that even with x =0.5, the partially substituted La1−x Sr x CoO3 catalysts still able to maintain the perovskite structure. The crystalline structure of a perovskite catalyst is an important factor that affects its catalytic activity for different reactions. It was reported in the literature that the partial substitution of La3+ by monovalent Ag+ turned the rhombohedral structure of La1- x Ag x Mn0.9Co0.1O3 catalyst to an orthorhombic structure, which is a more suitable structure for the n-hexane combustion reaction [14] . The importance of the perovskite structure on the catalytic activity for F–T synthesis was also described by Escalona et al. [5], when Fe was substituted by Co in LaFe1-xCoxO3 catalysts (from x =0 to x =1). The structure of LaFe1-xCoxO3 remained orthorhombic only for x <0.5, and then changed to a rhombohedral structure for substitution levels greater than 0.5, with the catalysts becoming less active in the F–T synthesis. This is possibly due to the orthorhombic structure being more stable even with a high number of cation vacancies [3,27] . In order to study the reducing properties of the La1−x Sr x CoO3 perovskites, all samples were reduced at the same conditions before XRD analysis. The XRD patterns of the La1−x Sr x CoO3 perovskites after reduction are shown in Fig. 3 . For the low strontium substituted samples (x =0 and 0.1), the perovskite rhombohedral structure remains after reduction at 450°C with H2. The typical diffraction peaks at 2θ ≈38–39° were weaker and broader compared to the fresh catalysts, suggesting the crystalline structure partly collapsed during the reduction. For the samples with x ≥0.2, the cubic perovskite structure was gradually decomposed during reduction, indicating that they have less thermal resistance under reducing atmosphere. It could be postulated that the progressive substitution of La3+ by divalent Sr2+ not only changed the structure symmetry and generated structure defects in La1- x Sr x CoO3 perovskites, but also destabilized the structure by the mismatch of the cation size between La3+ and Sr2+ (1.36Å and 1.44Å respectively), affecting their capacity to maintain their structure under reductive atmosphere. After reduction at 450°C, La2O3 (JCPDS- ICDD 74-2430), La2SrO x (JCPDS-ICDD 42-0343) and metallic cobalt (JCPDS-ICDD 15-0806) were formed as shown in Fig. 3. In Fig. 3C, the peak intensity of Co0 diffraction lines increased with increasing x. As the atomic ratio of (La+Sr)/Co in all La1- x Sr x CoO3 catalysts was equal to 1, the reduction of Co3+ in La1- x Sr x CoO3 occurred concomitantly with the formation of La2O3 and La2SrO x . Thus, the strong Co0 diffraction lines in higher strontium substituted catalysts (x ≥0.2) indicate that the reduced Co0 mainly resulted from the collapsed cubic perovskite structure. However, there was no obvious diffraction lines of Co0, La2O3 and La2SrO x found in samples with x =0 and 0.1, indicating that the partial reduction of the rhombohedral structure at 450°C resulted in Co0 and relating components highly dispersed over the catalyst surface [3,34]. After 24h catalytic performance test, the used catalysts were investigated by XRD analysis and the results are given in Fig. 4 . The XRD results show that the typical diffraction peak(s) associated with the perovskite structure in the range 2θ ≈38–39° could not be detected for all catalysts, and new phases corresponding to LaCO3OH (JCPDS-ICDD 26-0815), LaO2CO3 (JCPDS-ICDD 22-0642), La(OH)3 (JCPDS-ICDD 83-2034) and SrCO3 (JCPDS-ICDD 74-1491) were observed. It is evident that catalysts with low Sr level (x =0 and 0.1) were further reduced and their rhombohedral structure collapsed during the F–T synthesis, due to the presence of reducing atmosphere (H2) that promoted the formation of active Co0 sites and related La2O3 and La2SrO x . In parallel, a part of the La2O3 and La2SrOx formed during the reduction (see Fig. 3) further reacted with side products H2O or/and CO2 to produce LaCO3OH, La(OH)3, LaO2CO3 and SrCO3 [18]. As expected, with increasing strontium substitution, the peak intensity of Co0 and SrCO3 gradually increased. However, the peak intensity of LaCO3OH decreased significantly with increasing x, due to the decrease in lanthanum concentration in the catalyst. 3.1.3 SEM The SEM micrographs in Fig. 5 (left) do not show large morphological differences among the fresh La1-x Sr x CoO3 perovskite samples with different Sr substitution levels: the dominant morphologies are polyhedral grains, with an inhomogeneous size distribution. The LaCoO3 powder showed a wide range of particle size from 50–300nm (measured from SEM pictures), with 80% of powder diameter between 150 and 250nm. On the contrary, the particle size distribution of strontium substituted catalysts was much narrower (100–200nm), with a smaller average particle diameter compared to the un-substituted one. The similar particle size distribution for the substituted catalysts did not affect surface area significantly, in accordance with the BET results (Table 1). On the other hand, the SEM analyses show some variations in the morphologies of La1- x Sr x CoO3 perovskite catalysts after reaction (Fig. 5, right). The La1- x Sr x CoO3 perovskite catalyst with x =0.1 was less affected by sintering and retained a fine crystal size after reaction (100–200nm). However, for catalysts with x =0.2 and 0.3, the main particle size was increased from 100–200nm before reaction, to 200–300nm after reaction. 3.2 Reduction properties of La1−x Sr x CoO3 perovskites The H2-TPR profiles of the prepared La1−x Sr x CoO3 perovskite catalysts are displayed in Fig. 6 . Between 90°C and 800°C, all the reduction peaks can be assigned to the reduction of Co3+, as La3+ and Sr2+ are not reduced under such experimental conditions [35]. It was observed that the reduction properties of La1−x Sr x CoO3 perovskites were significantly affected by the partial substitution of lanthanum with strontium. For low strontium substituted samples (x ≤0.1), there were two main reduction steps. The first one at 400°C corresponds to the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+, in good agreement with the literature [36,37]. However, the small shoulder at higher temperature of the first peak (x ≤0.1) suggests that a small amount of cobalt was directly reduced to Co0 [11,34,38]. The second peak between 600°C and 750°C relates to the complete reduction of Co2+ to Co0. For higher strontium substituted catalysts (x ≥0.2), the reduction peaks shifted to lower temperatures compared to that for x ≤0.1 samples: the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ and, to a lesser extent, to Co0 occurred at 200–450°C with two peaks at 250°C and 400°C while the main peak of Co2+ to Co0 shifted to 500°C [18] . The existence of Co0 at the lower reduction temperature, as also observed in the XRD analysis after reduction at 450°C (Fig. 3C) confirmed the one-step reduction mechanism of Co3+ to Co0 in La1- x Sr x CoO3. With the increase of strontium content in the perovskites, the number of reduction peaks continuously increased while the reduction temperatures of the different Co species were decreased significantly [26]. Furthermore, the substitution of La3+ by Sr2+ in LaCoO3 perovskite samples generates oxygen vacancies to compensate and preserve the electroneutrality of the perovskite [39]. It is postulated that the partial strontium substitution facilitates the reducibility of the La1−x Sr x CoO3 perovskite catalysts [40]. The quantification of the total TPR reduction peak areas can be taken as an indication of H2 consumption for Co reduction in the perovskite structure. The results in Table 2 show a positive relationship between relative TPR peak area of La1−x Sr x CoO3 perovskite at 800°C (TPR peak area of La1−x Sr x CoO3/TPR peak area of LaCoO3 ×100, per gram of catalyst) and Sr substitution levels. With increasing Sr substitution is a higher Co molar content in the catalyst due to the relative atomic mass of Sr being lower than that of La (87.62g/mol and 138.91g/mol, respectively). The relative TPR peak area per mole cobalt at lower temperature of 450°C has a similar trend, as can be seen in Fig. 7 . Also observed is that the increase in relative peak area is much higher at 450°C in comparison to 800°C. The results in Fig. 7 also indicate that the catalyst LaCoO3 has the lowest Co reduction level and might not be fully reduced at low (450°C) and high temperature (800°C). The TPR results suggest the substitution of strontium improves the reducibility of the La1−x Sr x CoO3 catalysts not only by lowering the reduction temperature but also by higher Co reduction level. As indicated before, the La1−x Sr x CoO3 catalyst with x =0.4 has a higher tendency to sinter, hence a slower reduction process and a lower relative peak area per mole Co at 450°C. The XRD results in Fig. 3 suggested that the Co0 in this catalyst was higher than the others with a broader and higher Co peak. 3.3 Catalytic activity The catalytic activity of the prepared La1-x Sr x CoO3 perovskite for F–T synthesis was investigated. The conversion of the reactants was monitored frequently during the experimental time period. A typical CO conversion as a function of the reaction time is given in Fig. 8 . After catalyst aging (stabilisation) time of about 12h, CO conversion was stable for rest of the experiment time, with unnoticeable catalyst deactivation within a 24h reaction time. The mean conversion values during the stable period were used as reactant conversion in this work. The CO and H2 conversion over the prepared catalysts at reaction conditions described in Section 2.3 as a function of reaction temperatures are displayed in Fig. 9 . As expected, the results in Fig. 9 show that CO and H2 conversion in the F–T reaction over the prepared La1-x Sr x CoO3 catalysts increased with the reaction temperature. CO conversion was slightly higher than H2 conversion at high reaction temperatures (T =325°C and 350°C), indicating that the water gas shift reaction occurred, although only to a small extent. The catalytic results showed that the substitution of strontium has an inverse effect on the catalytic activity beyond x =0.1. CO and H2 conversions increased only for low strontium substitution levels (x ≤0.1) and then quickly decreased with increasing x values, with La0.9Sr0.1CoO3 catalyst exhibiting the best catalytic performance compared to the other catalysts prepared in this study. In order to explain the change in catalytic activity with strontium substitution, the physical and chemical characteristics of the catalysts need to be considered. In this study, there was no obvious difference in catalyst morphology and catalyst specific surface, therefore they will not affect the catalyst activity. Both TPR and XRD analysis demonstrated that the substitution of trivalent La3+ by divalent Sr2+ in LaCoO3 perovskite sample promotes the catalyst’s reducibility. The catalytic activity of the F–T catalysts are related to the effectiveness of the active centre—metallic Co [3,4]. According to Table 2 and Fig. 7, more metallic Co formed during reduction of the La1- x Sr x CoO3 perovskite catalysts with higher strontium substitution levels. The higher the Sr2+ substitution, the easier for La1-x Sr x CoO3 perovskites to reduce at 450°C and the more metallic Co available on the catalyst surface, which facilitates CO adsorption to form complexes with the Co0 active centres and initiates the Fischer–Tropsch reaction, and thus a higher catalytic activity can be expected. However, the inverse effect of strontium substitution on La1- x Sr x CoO3 perovskites catalyst activity was observed in this study. In order to explain the experimental results, the turnover frequency of the active centre Co (TOF, defined as mole of CO converted/mole of Co atom per second) of the catalysts was calculated and the results are given in Fig. 10 . The results show that the TOF value increases with increasing Sr substitution at low level (x ≤0.1), then deceases significantly with x higher than 0.1. This suggests that not all reduced cobalt act as active centres for the F–T reaction. The XRD results in Figs. 3 and 4 show that the metallic cobalt diffraction peaks in catalysts with x ≥0.2 were very strong. These results indicate that instead of being dispersed on the catalyst surface, Co0 active sites tend to sinter together and form larger Co0 particle in La1-x Sr x CoO3 perovskites catalysts with x ≥0.2, and thus caused the loss of active catalyst surface for the F–T reaction [5]. On the other hand, the lower intensity of Co diffraction peak of low strontium level catalysts after reaction (Fig. 4) confirms that the stable rhombohedral structure leads to a better dispersion of the active site Co0 over the catalyst surface, and thus a higher TOF value. In addition, SrCO3 was found on the surface of the catalysts after reaction, and the XRD peak intensity of this compound increases with increasing x (see Fig. 4). It was reported that this compound is inactive in F–T synthesis and covers the catalyst surface [18], which has a negative effect on the catalytic activity of the La1- x Sr x CoO3 perovskite catalysts and progressively partially inhibits the F–T reaction with increasing x. The XRD and SEM results in Figs. 4 and 5 show the changes of phase and particle size of the catalyst after 24h of testing. However, the results in Fig. 8 shows that the CO conversion was stable after the stabilisation time and remains within the analytical analysis error margin (±2%) until the completion of the experiment. The F–T synthesis with the La1- x Sr x CoO3 perovskite catalysts produced light hydrocarbons (gas phase) and liquid oxygenated products mostly, with a small portion of heavier hydrocarbons present in the liquid phase. In order to simplify the discussion of product selectivity, the products are grouped into four main product groups: carbon dioxide, methane, light hydrocarbons (C2–C5) and oxygenates (which also includes C5+ hydrocarbons, produced in very small amounts). A typical product selectivity of syngas conversion over the prepared catalysts at 300°C is given in Fig. 11 . Over all of the five catalysts with different strontium substitutions, there were no remarkable changes in the F–T product selectivity (less than 10%). It can be deduced that the strontium substitution of La1- x Sr x CoO3 has mild effects on the product selectivity at 300°C, considering the small uncertainties that may be present in the measurements. This is in agreement with the findings that the product selectivity in F–T synthesis is mainly affected by the B site substitution in perovskite catalysts [6,10] . The La0.9Sr0.1CoO3 catalyst proved to have the optimal strontium substitution level for La1- x Sr x CoO3 catalysts for the F–T process, displaying the best compromise between low active site Co0 sintering and reducibility improvement by strontium substitution. For these reasons, this catalyst showed the highest catalytic performance in syngas conversion compared with the other catalysts in this study. A comparison of the catalytic activity of several perovskite catalysts with different chemical compositions in the F–T synthesis, in terms of specific reaction rates in respect to the perovskite catalyst, is listed in Table 3 . Taking the catalyst activity (CO reaction rate) and reaction conditions into consideration, the La0.9Sr0.1CoO3 perovskite catalyst prepared in this study reached a high level of catalytic activity. 4 Conclusions Sr substituted La1−x Sr x CoO3 perovskite catalysts, active in the F–T synthesis, were successfully synthesised by co-precipitation. Increasing the partial substitution of lanthanum by strontium beyond x =0.1 modified the stable rhombohedral structure of La1- x Sr x CoO3 perovskites towards a less stable cubic symmetry, which is easier to reduce and favoured Co sintering during the reduction process. At high Sr substitution levels (x ≥0.2), SrCO3 inactive compound, which cover the catalyst surface, was also formed, further affecting the activity of La1−x Sr x CoO3 perovskite catalysts. As a consequence the catalytic activity decreased in the F–T reaction. At low strontium substitution level (x =0.1) the catalytic activity in F–T reaction was improved compared to LaCoO3 perovskite due to the improvement in reducibility, without the negative effect on Co0 active site dispersion. The optimal strontium substitution of La1- x Sr x CoO3 perovskite catalysts for syngas conversion is x =0.1. This work represents the first step in designing perovskite catalysts tailored for the selective production of higher alcohol in the Fischer–Tropsch process. In future work, catalyst selectivity will be further investigated with B site substitution effects on La0.9Sr0.1CoO3 perovskite for F–T synthesis. coredata.dc:description: Study of the catalytic activity of LaCoO3 perovskite catalysts with varying degrees of strontium substitution (La1-x Sr x CoO3) in the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis is presented for the first time in this paper. It was found that Sr substitution improves the catalyst’s reducibility and increasing strontium substitution beyond a threshold of 10mol% Sr has an inverse effect on the catalytic performance in the syngas conversion. For x ≤0.1, the catalysts exhibited a stable rhombohedral structure, which leads to well dispersion of active centre Co0 during the reduction process and displayed a high catalytic activity. For x ≥0.2 the catalyst structure was gradually changed, from a rhombohedral to a less stable cubic structure, and leads to Co0 sintering. The turnover frequency of Co atom in the Fischer–Tropsch reaction decreased significantly with increasing strontium substitution levels due to the loss of active catalyst surface. The La0.9Sr0.1CoO3 catalyst showed the highest catalytic activity in the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis.
coredata.dc:title: Structure and activity of strontium substituted LaCoO3 perovskite catalysts for syngas conversion
